I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
supplementary loan to the Republic of the Fiji Islands for the Suva–Nausori Water Supply and 
Sewerage Project. 
 

II. 

INTRODUCTION 

The  Government  of  the  Fiji  Islands  in  March  2000  requested  a  loan  from  the  Asian 
2. 
Development Bank (ADB) to finance the Suva–Nausori Water Supply and Sewerage Project.  1 
The request followed implementation of a technical assistance (TA) project for the preparation 
of  a  comprehensive  water  supply  and  sewerage  master  plan  and  a  feasibility  study  of  high-
priority investments identified in the plan.2 The ADB Board of Directors approved a loan for $47 
million  on  18  December  2003.  Approval  of  the  loan  was  delayed  following  the  coup  of  May 
2000. The Project is the first phase of a longer-term water supply and sewerage improvement 
strategy. The Loan Agreement was signed on 5 August 2004 and the loan became effective on 
8 December 2004. 
 
3. 
In  January  2009,  the  Government  asked  ADB  to  provide  supplementary  financing  to 
cover anticipated cost overruns caused by factors beyond the control of the interim Government, 
including  rising  global  commodity  prices  and  the  depreciation  of  the  US  dollar  against  regional 
currencies.  As  contracts  are  usually  denominated  in  US  dollars,  its  depreciation  resulted  in 
construction costs that were substantially higher than estimated when the Project was appraised. 
If  the  Project  is  not  completed,  it  will  not  deliver  the  intended  benefits  to  the  poor—improved 
access to water and sanitation services. This would have consequences for (i) the Fiji Islands, in 
terms  of  worsening  poverty;  and  (ii)  ADB,  in  terms  of  reputation  risk  associated  with  failing  to 
reach desired development outputs and outcomes. 
 

III. 

THE APPROVED PROJECT 

A. 

Project Rationale 

The Suva–Nausori regional water supply system supplies water to about 332,000 people 
4. 
(or 98% of the population) living within the Suva–Nausori area. When the Project was appraised 
in  2003,  consumers  throughout  the  service  area—particularly  those  living  at  the  edges  of  the 
water supply network—were subject to frequent water supply disruptions, primarily because of 
pump  equipment  failure  and  burst  water  supply  mains.  The  water  supply  network  was  and 
remains  subject  to  substantial  losses.  Unaccounted-for  water  is  estimated  at  55%.  The  area's 
two water treatment plants at Tamavua and Waila required rehabilitation to improve the quality 
and  quantity  of  treated  water.  The  water  transmission  and  distribution  systems  required 
optimization  to  distribute  the  produced  water  better  to  service  areas  in  relation  to  relative 
demand for water. 
 
5. 
The  wastewater  collection  and  treatment  system  faces  similar  issues.  In  central  Suva, 
anecdotal evidence suggested inflow and infiltration accounted for up to 90% of the sewer flows 
during wet weather. High tide also resulted in higher flows and salinity levels within the sewer 
system,  which  reduced  the  efficiency  of  the  area's  sewage  treatment  plants  and  substantially

and  sewerage  services  to  urban  centers  were  not  conducive  to  a  high  level  of  service  to 
consumers, and were not financially sustainable. The Water and Sewerage Department (WSD), 
a division of the Ministry of Public Utilities, Works and Transport (MPUWT), was responsible for 
the  planning,  design,  construction,  operation,  and  maintenance  of  urban  water  supplies  and 
sewerage  systems.  MPUWT  senior  staff  were  responsible  not  only  for  water  supply  and 
sewerage,  but  also  roads,  buildings,  and  mechanical  and  electrical  works.  Management 
information systems focused more on capital works than on operations or finances. 
 
7. 
The  Government’s  Strategic  Plan,  2003–2005  and  the  MPUWT  (then  known  as  the 
Ministry of Works and Energy) corporate plan for 2002 provided a framework for corporatization 
of water and sewerage services.3 The framework proposed the reorganization of the water and 
sewerage  section  of  MPUWT  into  an  autonomous  water  and  sewerage  corporation.  The 
Government  and  MPUWT  staff  recognized  the  need  to  plan  carefully  for  the  transition  to 
maintain  the  high  level  of  accessibility  to  services,  avoid  harmful  impacts  on  the  poor,  retrain 
and  redeploy  staff  rather  than  terminate  them,  and  avoid  substantial  tariff  increases  until 
services can be improved.

Objectives and Scope 

The  Project  will  contribute  to  higher  living  standards  in  the  Suva–Nausori  area, 
8. 
particularly  for  the  urban  poor.  The  objectives  of  the  Project  are  to  (i)  increase  the  delivery  of 
safe  water  supply  and  sewerage  services  to  the  Suva–Nausori  area  through  physical  and 
institutional  improvements,  and  (ii)  enhance  the  sustainability  of  water  supply  and  sewerage 
services throughout the Fiji Islands through appropriate institutional reforms. 
 
9. 
The  Project’s  outputs  include  (i)  increased  supply,  delivery,  and  reliability  of  potable 
water  in  the  Suva–Nausori  area;  (ii)  reduced  unaccounted-for  water;  (iii)  a  rehabilitated 
wastewater  collection  and  treatment  system;  (iv)  recovery  of  aquatic  ecosystems  that  have 
degraded  because  of  inadequate  sewerage  services;  (v)  strengthened  institutions  and 
legislative  frameworks  for  wastewater  management  and  environmental  management;  and  (vi) 
establishment of an entity dedicated to the provision of water and sewerage services in metered 
water  supply  areas,  operated  in  manner  similar  to  those  of  a  commercial  water  supply  and

A. 

Benefits 

58. 
The  economic  analyses  were  redone  for  the  Project.  In  the  absence  of  investments  in 
the Project, the status quo was assumed to continue. Quantified benefits for the Project's water 
supply components included (i) non-incremental benefits comprising (a) cost savings in meeting 
the  demand  of  new  customers  at  present  satisfied  demand  levels,  and  (b)  integration  of  the 
small  water  supply  system  servicing  Colo-I-Suva  into  the  Suva–Nausori  regional  water  supply 
scheme;  and  (ii)  incremental  benefits  comprising  (a)  meeting  suppressed  domestic  and 
commercial  demands,  and  (ii)  non-revenue  water  consumed  under  the  Project.  As  a  result  of 
low water supply pressure to some consumers and frequent water supply disruptions, supplies 
are assumed to have constrained demand. 
 

 Quantified  benefits  of  the  Project's sewerage  components  include  the avoided  costs  of 
59. 
(i) replacing and desludging septic tanks for the 9,300 urban allotments that will be connected to 
the sewerage system under the Project, and enforcement of laws compelling property owners to 
connect to sewerage systems where available; and (ii) replacing the Kinoya sewage treatment 
plant and existing sewers, which would be required in the absence of the Project's rehabilitation 
and augmentation works for the plant and rehabilitation of key sewers. 
 
60. 
The  economic  analyses  were  conducted  for  a  period  of  40  years,  including  an 
investment  period  of  9  years.  Taxes  and  duties  were  excluded  from  all  costs.  Economic 
investment costs included the updated cost estimates of the project components. The economic 
analyses yielded economic internal rates of return of 14.5% for the water supply component and 
12.7%  for  the  sewerage  component.  The  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  for  the 
water  supply  and  sewerage  components  combined  was  13.8%.  The  rates  of  return  were  less 
than the assumed economic opportunity cost of capital of 12% with respect to changes in some 
key  assumptions  and  risks.  Risk  of  further  delays  and  cost  increases  is  considered  small  as 
implementation  is  advanced.  Sustainability  throughout  the  life  of  the  Project  is  supported 
through the tariff mechanisms. Details of the economic analyses are in Appendix 8.

62.  Water Supply. Cost recovery from beneficiaries will be achieved through a revised tariff 
structure. The tariff will be set based on metered water consumption. A block tariff structure will 
be applied for domestic consumers for each 3-month billing cycle. A lifeline block will be applied 
for the first 50,000 liters consumed, followed by an intermediate block applied for consumption 
between 50,000 and 100,000 liters, and a high block for consumption exceeding 100,000 liters 
per billing cycle. A single volumetric tariff will apply to commercial and government consumers.

Sewerage. Cost recovery from beneficiaries will be achieved through the application of a 
sewerage  tariff  for  those  connected  to  the  sewerage  system.  The  tariff  will  be  set  based  on 
metered water consumption and applied by WAF as a separate line item on customers’ water 
bills.

At a minimum, the water and sewerage tariffs will be set to cover the costs of O&M and 
management during the first year of the revised tariff structure. It will be increased annually over 
2  years  to  achieve  full  recovery  of  O&M  costs,  depreciation,  and  debt  servicing.  The 
Government  will  fund  any  gap  between  actual  tariffs  and  those  required  to  achieve  full  cost

service  the  proposed  Housing  Authority  development  at  Navitoka,  development  of  an  asset 
register  and  geographic  information  system  (GIS)  system,  and  purchase  of  computers  and 
equipment for the National Water Quality Laboratory and the National Pump Workshop. By not 
including these components in the Project, the estimated cost overrun has been reduced from

Rewa  Run-of-the-River  Scheme.  While  the  raw  water  sources  for  the  Suva–Nausori

regional water supply need to be augmented, as proposed through the Project's Rewa run-of-
the-river  scheme,  the  Government  considered  it  prudent  to  delay  development  of  new  water

capacity  of  the  area’s  two  water  treatment  plants  at  Waila  and  Tamavua  (even  after  the 
rehabilitation and augmentation works at both plants are completed under the Project) is lower 
than  the  demand  for  treated  water.  Both  plants  operate  at  more  than  120%  of  their  rated

periods of high flow in the Waimanu River and Savura Creek. The development of a new water 
source  preferably  should  be  in  conjunction  with  the  development  of  a  new  water  treatment 
facility to service Nausori, the Rewa Delta area, and some areas north of Baulevu. The cost to 
develop a new water source and water treatment facility is estimated at $35 million, well beyond 
the project budget. This component could be included in a possible future phase of the Project.

relocated when the earthworks begin. To mitigate this risk, the Government decided to shelve 
the construction of the Navitoka sewerage scheme until the earthworks for the subdivision are 
complete. The extension of the sewerage network to Navitoka could also be financed through a 
possible future phase of the Project.

tank  built  to  building  code  requirements  is  F$4,000  (or  F$267  per  year).  Because  of  the 
relatively high household occupancy rate in the Suva–Nausori area (5.5 persons), septic tanks 
require pumping out on average once every 3 years. The average septic tank pumping out cost 
is F$500 (or F$167 per year). 
 
13.  
Existing sewers in the low-lying sections of the Suva–Nausori area, including the Suva 
central business district (CBD) and Nausori town, are dilapidated and prone to leaks. Many of 
the sewers are more than 60 years old, constructed from concrete, and located below the mean 
sea  level.  Seawater  that  leaks  into  the  sewers  is  pumped  to  the  Kinoya  and  Nausori  sewage 
treatment  plants,  adding  to  the  costs  of  operating  the  sewerage  system.  A  survey  in  1999  to 
estimate the volume of sea water entering the Suva City sewers concluded that more than 50% 
of the inflow to the Kinoya sewage treatment plant was seawater. The high seawater content in 
sewage  inflow  to  the  Kinoya  plant  has  resulted  in  accelerated  dilapidation  of  the  mechanical 
systems. 
 
14.  
The sewage pump stations that pump sewage from collector and trunk sewers within the 
area  are  also  highly  dilapidated  and  frequently  are  out  of  service.  This  results  in  a  buildup  of 
potentially lethal hydrogen sulfide gas, which is (i) an occupational health and safety issue for 
sewer  system  operators,  and  (ii)  extremely  corrosive  to  concrete  and  metallic  structures.  The 
combination of high seawater content and hydrogen sulfide gas within the sewers, if unchecked, 
will ultimately result in the failure of sewerage system, which could require the replacement of 
sewers  and  the  entire  Kinoya  sewage  treatment  plant.  The  replacement  cost  of  the  sewers  at 
current prices is estimated at F$45 million within the Suva CBD and F$9 million in Nausori town. 
The  cost  to  replace  the  Kinoya  plant  is  estimated  at  F$30  million.  The  Project's  sewerage 
components, particularly the inflow and infiltration (leak) reduction component, the rehabilitation 
of  the  Kinoya  plant,  and  the  rehabilitation  of  major  and  minor  sewage  pump  stations,  will 
significantly  delay  the  need  for  the  replacement  of  sewers  and  the  Kinoya  sewage  treatment 
plant. For the purposes of this economic analysis, the replacement of the Kinoya plant has been 
assumed  to  be  required  in  2015.  The  replacement  of  sewers  in  the  Suva  CBD  has  been 
assumed to be required in 2015 and for Nausori town in 2020. 
 
15.  
The  estimated  EIRR  for  the  sewerage  component  of  the  Project  is  12.7%.  Sensitivity 
tests for the project sewerage component yield EIRRs of less than 12% under adverse changes 
in some of the assumptions (Table A8.3).

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Poor  persons  in  the  Suva–Nausori  area  suffer  from  poor  quality  of  water  supplies,  lack  of  sanitation,  and  pollution  of  the 
streams and underground water. Infantile diarrhea is common, and many households are forced to boil their drinking water to 
purify it, which is costly. 
 
The Project will help provide potable water without frequent service interruptions, which are common for the majority of poor 
households in the project area. It will also make sewage collection available, although with a lower coverage than water, to a 
substantial number of poor households. Further, the Project will help improve the quality of water in the streams and coastal 
areas along which many poor people live. It will substantially benefit the poor by improving the quality of their water supply, 
improving  their  sanitation,  reducing  pollution  and  eliminating  the  need  to  boil  drinking  water  for  those  with  pipes  or  water 
connections. Since the cost of water and sewerage will decrease for the poor, the net benefit flows will be substantial. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                 Targeting Classification: General intervention (GI) 
1. Key Issues  
Some  of  the  poorest  households  in  the  Suva–Nausori  area  have  limited  access  to  safe  water  and  adequate  sanitation. 
Consequently, they are at greater risk than the general community for waterborne diseases. The poorest households cannot 
afford access to the  water supply  or to better sanitation facilities, resulting in more  health risks, environmental degradation, 
and  loss  of  amenities.  The  Project  directly  benefits  the  poorest  households  in  the  Suva–Nausori  area  by  increasing  the 
coverage  and  the  level  of  service  of  the  water  supply  and  sewerage  systems.  Poor  households  will  also  benefit  from 
environmental improvements resulting from better wastewater management services. 
 
2. Design Features  
The  Project’s  water  supply  component  will  help  reduce  health  risks,  such  as  infantile  diarrhea,  that  are  caused  by  the  lack  of 
water and contamination of water arising from low pressure in the piped system. It will also provide water for cooking, washing, 
and bathing, and reduce the need to boil  water. Improvements to sewage disposal to prevent contamination of  waterways  will 
benefit the poorest residents who live in swampy, low-lying, poorly draining areas near the coast, such as in Vatuwaqa and along 
the Samabula River. Residents of these communities use these waterways for fishing and supplementing their food sources. The 
environmental benefits of the Project’s sewerage component will improve the quality of life for the poorest people. Because of the 
global financial crisis and recent political events, more households in the Suva–Nausori area are facing hardship. 
 

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
The 2002 urban Household Income and Expenditure Survey (HIES) found that about 45% of housing in the project area was 
of  lower  standard  than  that  in  settlements,  Housing  Authority  units,  squatter  areas,  or  urban  villages.  The  2002  HIES  also 
found that 26.5% of the urban population lived in settlements, with an additional 10.3% living in squatter areas. Those living in 
Housing Authority or Public Rental Board flats accounted for 5.3% of the urban population, and urban villages accounted for 
4.5%.  The  2002  HIES  also  noted  that  the  highest  unemployment  rate  (23.1%)  was  found  in  the  urban  villages,  closely 
followed by squatter areas (19.8%), Housing Authority or Public Rental Board flats (17.6%), and settlements (15.8%). It was 
further  noted  that  77.2%  of  the  unemployed  had  achieved  a  secondary  level  education,  and  15%  had  post-secondary 
education.  The  Central  and  Eastern  Division  urban  areas—primarily  the  Suva–Nausori  corridor—accounted  for  55%  of 
unemployment. Of these unemployed, just more than half were living in low-quality housing, squatter settlements, or villages, 
where the findings of the participatory assessment of hardship conducted under the ADB technical assistance for preparation 
of  national  poverty  reduction  strategies  in  Pacific  developing  member  countries  in  February–March  2003  suggested  that 
access to safe water and sanitation is the poorest. 
 
Although the 2002 urban HIES reported that 96% (up from 93% in 1996) of households in the project area had access to a 
safe  water  supply,  this  figure  is  misleading.  While  many  households  have  access  to  a  piped  supply,  this  is  frequently 
interrupted and poor quality. Of the remainder, 2.2% used a communal standpipe, while 1.5% obtained water from rainwater 
tanks,  wells,  rivers,  or  some  other  method.  Communal  standpipes  were  located  only  in  informal  settlements  and  villages. 
Significantly, only one household indicated it was obtaining water from a river or creek, and this was not its sole source.
